title: Please provide opinion on the use of `continue` in loops.
body:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/continue#Description

Crockford says NO, but is a little terse as to why leaving the door open for debate:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11728757/why-are-continue-statements-bad-in-javascript

Thanks,

title: Adopt a commit message style?
body:
Hello, guardians of reasonable javascript style! It appears that you also follow some sort of a commit message style (but I could not find its description). Would you like to adopt some formal commit message style (like [jquery style](http://contribute.jquery.org/commits-and-pull-requests/#commit-guidelines), [angular style](https://github.com/angular/angular.js/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit) or maybe your own)?

Here is how commit history looks in those projects: [jquery core](https://github.com/jquery/jquery/commits/master) and [angular.js](https://github.com/angular/angular.js/commits/master)

title: Consider changing the maximum amount of characters per line from 100 to 80
body:
While the size of computer screens have increased, long line readability hasn't become an easier task for the human mind. Especially, if developers want to work on multiple snippets of code at once, lines should be narrow enough to avoid the appearance of horizontal scrollbars. Terminals also provide 80 columns of space per line, which is the legacy of the IBM punch card.

Further discussion can be read about the 80 chars per line coding standard [here](http://programmers.stackexchange.com/questions/148677/why-is-80-characters-the-standard-limit-for-code-width).

title: allowShortCircuit and allowTernary in no-unused-expressions
body:
It's pretty common to write e.g.

``` js
a && a();
```

Currently this fails the `no-unused-expressions` validation. However, using `allowShortCircuit` would allow this usage.

title: Change 'conjunctions' to 'contractions'
body: The word "don't" is a contraction, not a conjunction.

title: The `imports` in tests for the rule `import/no-extraneous-dependencies`
body:
Some of the dependencies in test code are in `devDependencies`. When I lint the test code, some errors appear:

``` shell
  1:1  error  'chai' should be listed in the project's dependencies, not devDependencies  import/no-extraneous-dependencies
```

This error is unexpected.

title: Trailing commas in function arguments
Legacy now requires comma-dangle in object literals
body: Is this intentional?

title: File naming conventions
body:
I'm trying to figure out a good file naming convention for my app and it seems like you guys have a great react style guide. There is one thing that is kind of confusing:

> Use the filename as the component name. For example, ReservationCard.jsx should have a reference name of ReservationCard. However, for root components of a directory, use index.jsx as the filename and use the directory name as the component name

This sentence doesn't really make sense to me:

> However, for root components of a directory, use index.jsx as the filename and use the directory name as the component name

In your example [here](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/master/react#naming), it states that this is bad:

```
// bad
import Footer from './Footer/index';
```

Isn't that "bad" example what you're referring to when you say "for root components of a directory, use index.jsx as the filename and use the directory name as the component name"?

Can you give an example of what would go in the index file?

Thanks!

title: generator-star-spacing rule change incompatible with async/await
body:
The `generator-star-spacing` rule was activated on the back of #887 and [included](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/commit/8e125fa07cd9214b5e31e59095707ffae3284d13) in the v4.0.0 release. Unfortunately this rule breaks linting in codebases that use async/await syntax (see https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/6528).

The [guidance](https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/6528#issuecomment-228324958) from ESlint is to use the `eslint-plugin-babel` flavour of the `generator-star-spacing` rule instead. So async/await users upgrading to v4.0.0 will need to apply the following overrides to continue linting:

```
    'generator-star-spacing': 0,
    'babel/generator-star-spacing': [2, { 'before': false, 'after': true }]
```

As airbnb don't take a dependency on `eslint-plugin-babel`, this obviously isn't a fix you should be expected to adopt upstream. However, I wonder whether you should highlight this incompatibility in your readme? Perhaps a note added as 11.4?

I'd be happy to ping you a PR but wanted to get your take on it first.

title: Added link to Mozilla documentation on Function#bind
Consider removing the ES5 styleguide.
body:
It's probably out of sync with the main styleguide and we should be promoting the latest and greatest rather than clinging onto JS from 10 years ago.

I therefore propose we deprecate the ES5 folder.

We can move it out of this repo or perhaps even just point to a commit which has the file if people would like to view it.

title: Document for-in restricted usage
body:
Fix https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/issues/840

Text belongs to https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/issues/851#issuecomment-213834028

title: Update for ESLint 3.0.0
body:
ESLint 3.0.0 was recently released. I don't see any breaking changes
that affect our configuration, so it seems like we can support the
currently supported range in addition to 3.0.0+.

http://eslint.org/blog/2016/07/eslint-v3.0.0-released

I needed to fix a couple of minor things to get tests to pass.

title: Remove leading underscores for private properties
body:
- It follows [ES6 styleguide](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#naming--leading-underscore)
- eslint plugin is configured this way : `'no-underscore-dangle': [2, { allowAfterThis: false }],`

title: A question about react stateless function
body:
In the link
https://github.com/reactjs/redux/issues/1176

I found that stateless function is slow because of rendering, so they recommend React function even if it is stateless.

Is there any other reason you suggest stateless function?
